_header: Wit ye not where there stands a little town
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the Manciple’s Prologue of the Canterbury Tales — 104 lines in rhyming couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
WEte ye nought where stondith a litel tounwhiche that cleped is
                    bobbe vp & doun…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…tell on thi tale Maunciple I the praywel quod he herkeneth
                    what I say
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
…And next folwyng bigineth the Maunciple (f. 262); the Maunciple
                    (RT); Here endith the Maunciple his prolog… (f. 263v)

BodBar20.First Lines:
WOte ȝe not where stant a lytul tounwiche þat is clepid
                    bob vp & doun…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…Telle on þy tale þou manciple I the prayWel sir
                    quod he now herkenyth what I saye
BodBar20.Attributed Title:
…and / here begynnyth þe prologe of þe Maunciple (f. 255);
                    here endith þe prologe… (f. 256v)

Bod414.First Lines:
[W]Ote ye not wher þere stant a litle townWhich that clepid is
                    Bobupandoun…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…Telle on thy tale Manciple I thee preyWel sir coth he now
                    herkneth what I sey

BodLauMis600.First Lines:

                    ganuþ loo þis dronke wight…

                    herken what I saye

                    maunciple… (f. 264v)

                    what I say

CULGg427.First Lines:
WOte ȝe not where there stant alityl tounWhich that I clepid
                    is Bobbe vp & doun…
CULGg427.Last Lines:
…Telle on thyn tale manciple I the preyeWeel sere quod he
                    herkenyth what I schal seye
CULGg427.Attributed Title:

                        393v)

CamFitzMc181.Transcription:
WOte ye not wher ys a TounThat me calleth bob up and dounThere
                    our oste spake now lete se with þe bestWho schal tell as meryly as
                    hath þe presteCome nere Mauncypull and tell a tale hereAlle Redy
                    oste quoth he with gode chereBut have me excused ful sympully y kanAnd
                    with a glad chere his tale he bygan
CamFitzMc181.Note:
IX.3-104 omitted; six spurious lines follow IX.2 (see
                    above).
